Now it‚Äôs time to go back out there and do some serious rockin‚Äô.‚Äù For George Thorogood & The Destroyers, serious rockin‚Äô will always be what they do best. And for 2025, The Baddest Show On Earth Tour will bring the guitar-slinging, amp-blasting, roof-shaking rock party like never before.¬†

George and longtime Destroyers Jeff Simon (drums), Bill Blough (bass), Jim Suhler (guitar) and Buddy Leach (saxophone) are now taking all the drum-bashing, bass-pounding, sax-wailing, monster guitar energy of the past five decades and pouring it into The Baddest Show On Earth Tour, with ‚Äúthe boogie-blues Sinatra‚Äù (Classic Rock History) as its relentless ringmaster. ‚ÄúIf the circus makes everyone feel like a kid again, this tour will make you feel like a teenager,‚Äù George says with a grin. ‚ÄúI consider us to be a musical high-wire act that works without a net, and we‚Äôll be bringing all the danger, thrills, and fun that our audiences can handle. Because that‚Äôs what great rock & roll is all about.‚Äù

bands: The PettyBreakers - A Tribute to Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers
shows.description:
‚ÄúThe World‚Äôs Greatest Tribute to Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers!‚Äù So say Katie Daryl, Mark Cuban and Ryan Seacrest of AXS-TV as they selected the PettyBreakers to perform on their hit TV show in 2014.

The PettyBreakers is the nation‚Äôs premier ‚ÄúTom Petty and the Heartbreakers‚Äù tribute act.¬† Based out of Southern California, this band accurately recreates the sights, sounds and concert experience of a Tom Petty concert. All the classics‚Ä¶ American Girl‚Ä¶Break Down‚Ä¶ Free Fallin‚Äô‚Ä¶ Mary Jane‚Äôs Last Dance‚Ä¶Refugee‚Ä¶ Runnin‚Äô Down a Dream‚Ä¶ and so many more... perfectly reproduced. Playing to packed houses all over the U.S., the band is comprised of excellent musicians who have performed and recorded with international artists. The PettyBreakers honor the music of this legendary American icon.

Los Angeles psych-punk shapeshifters Frankie and the Witch Fingers have spent the last decade mutating their sound into bold, electrifying new forms. Their latest release, Trash Classic (via Greenway Records and The Reverberation Appreciation Society), plunges into a sewer-slick fusion of proto-punk venom, fractured new wave, and industrial grime. Brimming with wiry synths, angular melodies, and grooves that squirm and bite, it‚Äôs all delivered with a sly, playful wink. Fueled by relentless global touring and a fierce DIY ethos, the band has shared stages with OFF!, Ty Segall, Oh Sees, Cheap Trick, and ZZ Top, cementing their place as one of the most unforgettable live acts around. Frankie and the Witch Fingers continue to morph, dragging listeners into whatever warped direction their experimental journey takes next.

Throughout his prolific career, Femi Kuti has stood as a powerful voice for justice, carrying forward the revolutionary Afrobeat legacy pioneered by his father, Fela Kuti. Known for his unflinching critiques of political corruption and social inequality, Femi‚Äôs heady mix of funk, jazz and highlife has always been a tool for resistance and change.
But on Journey Through Life, his new album out in 2025 via Partisan Records, Femi turns inwards, balancing the political themes that have defined his career with deeply personal reflections on family, life, and inner growth: ‚ÄúI wanted to talk more about me, about my thoughts and the goals and values that have guided me all these years and led me to where I am now. ¬†I‚Äôve never done that on an album before‚Äù says Femi.¬†
Femi began his career as a member of Fela's legendary band, Egypt ‚Äô80, and briefly stepped into the role of frontman when his father was imprisoned on fabricated charges in 1984. In 1986 he left to create his own band Positive Force, and has been forging his own style of Afrobeat ever since, adding doses of R&B, rock, and hip hop to the traditional Yoruba rhythms and jazzy horns. Lyrically, however, his focus has remained firmly on issues of power, oppression, and social injustice, and his activism has extended beyond music through collaborations with organizations like Global Citizen and his role as a UNICEF goodwill ambassador.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been so political, and I will continue to be, but when I look back, my life has not only been about this. Yes, I get very depressed about my immediate environment and when I travel and I see sadness, but I also see how my music brings joy to people who come to my concert. I am a very homely person, I love my children very much, and I thought it was important for people to see that‚Äù says Femi.¬†
The title track encapsulates Femi‚Äôs introspective journey, with his soaring sax solo mirroring the song's uplifting message. Against a backdrop of sturdy, syncopated rhythms, he encourages listeners to ‚Äúenjoy and learn from experience/Make the best of your journey through life,‚Äù all while reflecting on its ephemeral nature.¬†
Despite his more contemplative focus, Femi hasn‚Äôt turned his back to the wider world, and the politically charged energy that has long been a hallmark of his music is still strong across the album. On ‚ÄúPolitics Don Expose Them‚Äù he refers back to one of his most famous tracks, 1998‚Äôs ‚ÄúSorry Sorry‚Äù, which ¬†‚Äî in turn echoing the fierce message of Fela's ‚ÄúZombie‚Äù ¬†‚Äî claimed there was no difference between ¬†the outgoing military regime and the politicians who were about to take power. ‚ÄúSo this is just to say, I told you so. Politics has exposed the true character of our politicians, they are just as corrupt and have put us in a very bad predicament‚Äù says Femi. In true Kuti style, the biting lyrics are woven into melodious sax lines, ¬†impossibly catchy horn riffs, and squelchy synths ‚Äî ¬† truly embodying the spirit of Femi‚Äôs signature ‚Äúsweet music with a bitter message.‚Äù¬†
‚ÄúAfter 24 Years‚Äù, which has been recorded for the first time with new lyrics after decades of being a fan favorite in Lagos‚Äô New Africa Shrine, echoes similar sentiments, with the chorus powerfully declaring: ‚Äúafter 24 years/with confidence we fit say/These politicians failed the nation‚Äù over triumphant horn riffs and a buoyant key motif.¬†
The New African Shrine, which Femi runs with his sister Yeni, ¬†was established in 2000 to honor Fela‚Äôs legacy, and it continues to serve as a place of resistance and proud cultural expression. Femi‚Äôs Sunday night performances with his band The Positive Force have become iconic, and every year the Felabration festival celebrates Afrobeat‚Äôs impact on post-colonial Africa.¬†
As Femi reflects on his journey so far, he revisits several other old tracks, including three ‚Äî ¬†‚ÄúLast Mugu,‚Äù ‚ÄúOga Doctor,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThink My People Think‚Äù ‚Äî ¬†dating back to the early '90s, not only in an effort to preserve his legacy but to reshape it in a way that mirrors the person he has become, both spiritually and musically. ‚ÄúCorruption Na Stealing‚Äù for example, ¬†initially recorded in 2018 for One People One World, re-emerges with a bolder, funkier sound that amplifies its message:‚ÄúI never liked the mood really, I didn‚Äôt like the feeling it left me with. But when we played it live at The Shrine, it was one of the best, so I wanted to capture that feeling for this album‚Äù he explains. ¬†Similarly, ‚ÄúShotan‚Äù, ¬†originally recorded live in 2004, takes on new life in this album with a fresh studio version infused with a raw, punk energy.¬†
While he has always composed all of his own music, this marks the first time he has also been in charge of every aspect of production: ‚ÄúIt was very important for me to do it this time, and probably for my future work. ¬†I am at a stage where I want to emphasize my creativity, expressing how I truly feel from deep within. I want to delve deeper‚Äîspiritually, socially, and politically as well.‚Äù¬†
This is particularly clear on ¬†‚ÄúWork on Myself‚Äù, where Femi candidly reflects on his feelings of helplessness in the face of global turmoil and his commitment to personal growth as a way to navigate it. ‚ÄúThere is so much chaos around me, and sometimes I feel like I have no power to change anything. I feel so helpless, and I know a lot of people around the world feel the same. My way is to keep working on myself, to always become a better person and better musician‚Äù says Femi, adding that the moments of self reflection while working on this particular track have helped shape his ‚Äúmind and soul‚Äù: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt forget, I am just a medium, I don‚Äôt know where the inspiration comes from, the more humble I am the more this ideas will come and and guide my life and prepare me for the future.‚Äù
This album is deeply personal for Femi in another way, as it was written while his daughter was going through some serious health issues: ‚ÄúIt just made me reflect on a lot of things, and on my journey as a father.‚Äù It also follows Legacy+, the double album he worked on with his son Made: ¬†‚ÄúMaking music with my son reshaped the way I approach everything,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúEach album feeds into the next, and without that experience, I wouldn‚Äôt be where I am today.‚Äù¬†
Journey Through Life represents both a continuation and a departure for Femi Kuti. While he remains committed to using his music as a vehicle for political and social change, this album marks a new chapter, one where his inner reflections take center stage. ‚ÄúI think I will keep going in this direction,‚Äù he says of his future work. ‚ÄúThis album has helped me learn more about myself, and I hope it can inspire others to do the same.‚Äù¬†
At 62, Femi stands at a creative crossroads, poised to explore new depths while staying true to the roots that have shaped him. Journey Through Life offers a profound and personal reflection on the values, struggles, and triumphs that have defined Femi‚Äôs life, both on stage and off.

Ambrosia, the band known and loved by a multitude of fans since the 1970‚Äôs, is now more alive and compelling than ever. This 5-time Grammy Nominated ensemble is exploring new musical territory and bringing an exceptional musical performance to stages everywhere.¬†

In 1970, four young musicians from the South Bay of Los Angeles, came together to create a new moving and invigorating style of music. Joseph Puerta, Christopher North, David Pack, and Burleigh Drummond produced a sound that was immediately recognized. Today, Ambrosia is three of the original members with the addition of guitarist Doug Jackson, contributing keyboardist Mary Harris, and powerful lead vocals of Kipp Lennon (from the band Venice).¬†

Always exploring the possibilities of progressive, classical, and world influences ‚Äì with tangled roots of soul, rhythm, and blues ‚Äì Ambrosia is continuing to entertain their original fans while still engaging newer audiences.¬†

Originally labeled as America‚Äôs answer to the progressive invasion of English acts Yes and King Crimson, the group quickly proved itself with a unique blend of aural landscapes. Their musical styles attracted the collaboration with cultural icons Leonard Bernstein, Kurt Vonnegut Jr., Alan Parsons, Bruce Hornsby, Michael McDonald, Edgar Winter, Dave Mason, Gary Wright, Al Stewart, and others. Ambrosia had toured extensively with Fleetwood Mac, Heart, and the Doobie Brothers.¬†

During Ambrosia‚Äôs early recording history they garnered 5 Grammy Nominations, received frequent radio airplay, and gained the admiration and respect of the musical community ‚Äì in addition to their sold out concerts around the world. Ambrosia achieved 5 Top 40 hit singles on Warner Bros. Records, released between 1975 and 1980, including ‚ÄúHow Much I Feel‚Äù and ‚ÄúBiggest Part of Me‚Äù. In 2015 the group released a new single, ‚ÄúHopes and Dreams‚Äù, which was featured on the series called The Sparrows that aired on the Fox television channel. As of 2017, the new Ambrosia material keeps coming.¬†

Bringing a breathtaking performance of their classic hits as well as new moving music, Ambrosia puts on a perfect show for any stage, casino, night club, festival, or special event.¬†

¬†‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how you do it!‚Äù¬†

‚ÄìJimmy Fallon (accolades from Jimmy himself after performance on the Jimmy Fallon Show)¬†

‚ÄúWith a solid set list and captivating performance, it‚Äôs evident that Ambrosia still has a lot in the proverbial rock tank.‚Äù ‚ÄìSteven Neff (Music Enthusiast Magazine)¬†

‚ÄúAmbrosia is one of my favorite bands. These guys are just wonderful to see live and hear their beautiful music. True and absolutely professional musicians. That‚Äôs why I keep going to see them every year.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄìBluesman (Review posted on Goldstar)

They say it ain‚Äôt where you‚Äôre from, it‚Äôs where you‚Äôre at. But for Angus Dowling, Jack ‚ÄòCool-Breeze‚Äô Crowther and Dr Elliot ‚ÄòLove Wisdom‚Äô O‚ÄôReilly, the character of their home, Australia‚Äôs idyllic Gold Coast, permeates every atom of the dreamlike, joyful, psychedelic music they create together as Babe Rainbow. ‚ÄúThe old Aquarius hippie connection is everywhere around here,‚Äù singer Angus says. ‚ÄúWe tap into it, and absorb it all.‚Äù And their new album, Slipper Imp And Shakaerator, is their most ‚Äúhomegrown‚Äù project yet ‚Äì a suite of maverick, zephyr-light acid-pop following its own north star and chasing subtle, slippery, subterranean grooves to delirious destinations.¬†
The trio grew up in Rainbow Bay, later relocating to nearby Byron Bay. An area of breathtaking natural beauty, where the waves are always strong, the magic mushrooms grow freely, and old, abandoned farm buildings abound. It was and remains the perfect locale for young dudes to play their music as loud as they want. ‚ÄúWe were 16 and 17 years old, working at Tropical Fruit World in Duranbah, cruising around the kiosks and listening to the Nuggets compilations,‚Äù remembers Angus, of the group‚Äôs earliest days. ‚ÄúJack and I met in the Australian youth choir as junior songbirds years before that, and he was still the only technical musical guy I knew, but I had the feeling we could all play this music we loved in our own way. We lived on an avocado farm up around then, in the macadamia orchard of the property. And it was so much fun making random noise while surrounded by the mangoes and the bush.‚Äù
The trio jammed tirelessly in those abandoned shacks, and as their sound began to develop, they booked shows in Brisbane, the nearest city, a two-hour drive away. While playing Brisbane, they crossed paths with King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard, who began to book the embryonic Babe Rainbow as opening band at their shows. ‚ÄúThis is before Gizz‚Äôs ‚Äòstadium-rock‚Äô period,‚Äù Dowling grins.
The Gizz connection would prove fortuitous for Babe Rainbow, who signed to the group‚Äôs Flightless label for their 2015 eponymous EP, and whose 2017 self-titled debut LP was produced by Gizzard King Stu Mackenzie. The album established a loyal following for Babe Rainbow, one which has only grown over the records since. And Babe Rainbow‚Äôs music itself has evolved across those years, as the band have travelled, toured the world and connected with new friends in faraway places. ‚ÄúEarly on, we got to play in California, came early, stayed late, caught a ton of good waves and met some of the best people in the world,‚Äù Angus says. ‚ÄúWe began rolling around the world, picking up new styles and collaborating with everybody.‚Äù¬†
This creative sprawl reached its apotheosis with 2022‚Äôs The Organic Band, which Angus remembers as coming together ‚Äúon the road, a lot of friends together. We met [drummer] Miles Myjavec from Sydney and began chucking ideas down. We were meeting amazing people in California and London and Paris just jamming and singing, everyone‚Äôs so happy, having the best time ever.‚Äù¬†
For the new album, however, Babe Rainbow have opted for a different approach ‚Äì one Angus says ‚Äúkeeps to the powers of the Rainbow‚Äù. The collaborations with all the free spirits they encounter along the way have been curtailed this time. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd done a few albums of us experimenting with people we met on the road and bringing in influence from everywhere,‚Äù says Angus. ‚ÄúThis is the first record since our debut EP where it‚Äôs just the ‚Äòoriginal Gs‚Äô, pushing the songwriting in the direction we want, without any groove geniuses around helping us in those really deep and special moments of writing a song.‚Äù This back-to-basics, back-to-the-source vibe explains the album‚Äôs enigmatic title, the (Bunyip) Slipper Imp and the Shakaerator, aka the Yeoman plow, a sub-soiler chisel plow designed for the more extreme conditions found in Australia, the ‚Äúrevolutionary new ripper of great strength ‚Äì haha!‚Äù says Angus.
The trio took over a massive warehouse on an old banana farm where they could get to work alongside friend and producer Timon Martin and magical Miles Myjavec on percussion and flute. The roots of the tracks often lay in riffs and figures cooked up by guitarist Jack Crowther. ‚Äú‚ÄòCool Breeze‚Äô has always got something going on‚Äù says Angus. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs always keen to jam, and Timon‚Äôs so good with helping to realise the potential of a song.‚Äù The key this time was not to overwork these early ideas, to give them space ‚Äúto flow, to grow‚Äù, he explains. ‚ÄúKeeping a loose feeling to the music is so important. An idea develops together outside but it doesn't take its wings until you take it into the studio. Every step of the way, I'm always trying to stay connected to Jack‚Äôs original moment of inspiration. We experiment with synths and drum machines and overdubs, and we love that, but we never wanna escape too far from the hippie power of the music. We're made of rainbow.‚Äù
That looseness and that true essence are key to the pleasures within Slipper Imp And Shakaerator. The album rambles gleefully wild, the jams running long but with purpose, lysergic harmonies loosely tethered to deftly funky rhythms loops and fragments of guitar that channel the lyricism of high-life (What Is Ashwagandha), the flash of 80s funk (Like Cleopatra, a glorious, sun-soaked pop banger in disguise), the white-heat of acid-rock (When The Milk Flows). There are haunting instrumental vignettes (Apollonia), nuggets of lo-fi introspection (Now And Zen), even a massive, ground-quaking, reggae-informed excursion starring old friend Stu Mackenzie (the woozy, wonderful Mt Dub), who also mixed the album.
Indeed, while the connection between the core Rainbow Babes here is crucial to the character of Slipper Imp And Shakearator, they weren‚Äôt working entirely alone. One key collaborator was singer Camille Jansen, who the group met through their friend and old band mate Maria Benz, and who joined them onstage on their recent US tour. ‚ÄúCami sang on all the songs on the album, but I feel we haven‚Äôt fully tapped into our connection together yet,‚Äù says Angus. ‚ÄúShe brings an insane new flavour, which is stupendous. It feels really cool and powerful to add her to this lineup.‚Äù
But ultimately, Slipper Imp And Shakearator is a celebration of all the colours of the Babe Rainbow ‚Äì the milk, Angus jokes. ‚ÄúI love the fact that, with all the touring and the changing tides, and hair, the creative relationship within the band still feels so strong. I feel so lucky to have this psychedelic family, which is really the essence of the band. We‚Äôre just a bunch of laid back surfers, cattlemen‚Äôs sons.‚Äù
But as Slipper Imp And Shakearator proves, these babes have access to powerful, home-baked psychedelic magic, and they aren‚Äôt reluctant to share. Come grab some ‚Äì all are welcome.

I Hear Thunder marks the long-awaited return of four-time Grammy-nominated artist Tab Benoit. Renowned for his distinctive guitar tone and Otis-Redding-esque voice, Benoit has been a captivating figure in the roots music world for over thirty years.
¬†
Tab's personal growth and advancement as a songwriter and musician have culminated in a benchmark recording. His new self-produced album, I Hear Thunder, for his imprint, Whiskey Bayou Records, is a testament to his fiery exuberance that first marked his career in 1992. The record not only showcases his artistic brilliance but also his profound commitment to environmental advocacy, a legacy that extends beyond the stage into the heart of the land that inspires his bluesy soul.¬†
¬†
On Benoit's forthcoming national tour, fans will be delighted to hear the new songs and selected tracks from his vast catalog. Benoit does more than play the blues; he defines its future while paying homage to its rich past.

¬†
On Benoit's forthcoming national tour, fans will be delighted to hear the new songs and selected tracks from his vast catalog. Benoit does more than play the blues; he defines its future while paying homage to its rich past.

WITCH - Sogolo (2025)¬†
Zamrock, the Afro-rock genre that swept southern Africa in the 1970s, was born in the Copperbelt region of northern Zambia, and WITCH was at the center of it all. In the beginning, lead singer Emmanuel ‚ÄòJagari‚Äô Chanda and the band looked for a name to match edgy rock sounds coming from Europe and America. First they tried Kingston Market, which sounded too reggae-ish, then they tried Footswitch, but there was a local artist called Dr Footswitch, so they shortened it to Switch, and then finally WITCH. ‚ÄúThe posters were handwritten,‚Äù Jagari recalled, ‚Äúso we would draw somebody on a broomstick.‚Äù Hot out of the gate, WITCH signed to Teal Records and began touring in a truck with a canopy emblazoned with the words: ‚ÄúTrespassers will be eaten‚Äù The graphic artist who wrote those words also gave the band its enduring acronym: We Intend To Cause Havoc. Jagari recalls, ‚ÄúThere was no hesitation. Everyone agreed‚Äù And the rest is history.¬†
Fast forward four decades, and Jagari, along with veteran keyboardist/composer Patrick Mwondela, now lead a new, multi-national formation of the band. Sogolo is their second 21st century release. It‚Äôs the follow up to Zango (2021), which was recorded against all odds in the same Lusaka studio that WITCH frequented in the ‚Äò70s‚Äîfunky and dilapidated, but with a vibe that heralded a reawakening for the band.¬†
All this came as a surprise to Jagari, who had been trying his hand at gemstone mining when filmmaker Gio Arlotta arrived in 2014 - during Zambia‚Äôs jubilee independence celebration - to begin work on his 2019 documentary WITCH (We Intend to Cause Havoc). The gemstone quest was a bust, but Jagari recalls, ‚ÄúSometimes when one door closes, another will open, and that turns out to be WITCH resurrected. Amazing! It has given me a new lease of life.‚Äù¬†
Sogolo was tracked in Berlin, during a 10-day break in the band‚Äôs 2024 tour schedule. The lineup included Cuban-Dominican percussionist Charlie Garmendia, guitarist Stefan Lilov, Jacco Gardner on bass, Nicola Mauskovic on drums, and two singers from Zambia, Hannah Tembo and Theresa Ng'ambi. ‚ÄúSometimes we just jammed,‚Äù says Jagari. ‚ÄúBut we tolerated one another and trusted their contributions. Fortunately, what has come out seems to be good. Each one feels they have contributed something.‚Äù ¬†
Sogolo means ‚Äúfuture, or front‚Äù echoing a longstanding ethic of the band, going back to their 1980 disco album, Moving On. Jacco Gardner produced Sogolo. ‚ÄúThe studio for Zango wasn't in use for bands for decades, so we had to really make it work,‚Äù he recalls. A more ‚Äúpractical‚Äù option turned out to be Big Snuff Studio in Berlin. ‚ÄúWe would all be together, and in shape because we're on tour, playing every night. So we had a good dynamic going as a band.‚Äù The studio was well-tooled but small, and time was tight. Jacco felt the pressure. ‚ÄúThis was a big deal,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe were contributing to the legacy of a legendary band with a dense discography and history.‚Äù¬†
Jagari‚Äôs song ‚ÄúKamusale‚Äù punches with crunchy guitar, crying vocals and a ‚ÄúHelter Skelter‚Äù vibe, but it‚Äôs based on a Bemba children‚Äôs game song. ‚ÄúChildren gather under the moonlight in the village and pretend to be preparing themselves for marriage,‚Äù says Jagari. ‚ÄúSo we are saying as kids, be careful who you pick. Don't follow the beauty of the face or body. Go deeper into the
character and make sure you are marrying the right person.‚Äù Funky and urgent, Jagari‚Äôs ‚ÄúQueenless King,‚Äù also deals with the perils of marriage, specifically what happens when family pressure forces a bad decision. ‚ÄúYou are enticed to marry someone because of her beauty, not knowing that her true colors are very cunning. In the end you discover her wicked ways. You end up being a queenless king.‚Äù¬†
The elders of WITCH strive to nurture younger musicians. ‚ÄúAt this stage in our life,‚Äù says Patrick, ‚ÄúWe would love to empower young musicians to use our platform. For us, it's not about chasing fame and fortune; it's making sure the legacy continues.‚Äù That‚Äôs how singers Theresa Ng'ambi and Hanna Tembo got recruited into the band during the Zango session.¬†
‚ÄúMachiriso,‚Äù a loping, groovy Afro-rap number, grew out of a duo bass jam between Jacco and Jagari during a lunch break. ‚ÄúWe were doing two basses,‚Äù recalls Jagari, ‚Äúand then Theresa came in to sing randomly. She's saying, ‚ÄòWe have gathered together as WITCH to give you the message of love and peace.‚Äô‚Äù The rolling ternary rhythms of ‚ÄúNibani‚Äù come from a sound check jam among the musicians. ‚ÄúWe didn't even know it was being recorded,‚Äù says Jacco. ‚ÄúNadi‚Äù is the hardest rocking track on the album. ‚ÄúWith that song,‚Äù says Jacco, ‚Äúwe tried to reference the heavy Zamrock sound.‚Äù That‚Äôs the garage band style that WITCH began with before verging into more complex progressive rock, then traditional rhythms, Afrobeat vibes, and in the early ‚Äò80s, disco. As Jacco put it, ‚ÄúWe had a lot to reference.‚Äù¬†
‚ÄúTiponde Madzi,‚Äù another track born from a hotel room jam, veers mback and forth between a ritualistic slow march and a rollicking 6/8 groove. Jagari explains that the words tell an old story in which animals gather looking for water by stomping on the earth. They compete for success, but in the end, it‚Äôs the humble tortoise who finds the water. ‚ÄúThe tortoise is the one they belittled. ‚ÄòWhat can you do? You have no strength.‚Äô So there‚Äôs a moral lesson: don't underestimate anyone.‚Äù¬†
Patrick says the essence of WITCH‚Äôs sound is emotion. ‚ÄúThis is how music touches people. It could be love, it could be war, it could be anything, but music is emotional.‚Äù Patrick‚Äôs reggae/gospel song ‚ÄúTotally Devoted‚Äù takes words from the Bible‚Äôs Psalm 23. ‚ÄúWe can go through problems, we can go through the valley of the shadow of death, but I fear no evil because God is with me.‚Äù Jagari notes that this song was inspired by Patrick‚Äôs traumatic experience. ‚ÄúWhile we were on tour in Chicago, Patrick fell ill,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúHe had bloodclots in his lungs, so it was a threat to his life, and he didn't finish the tour. So he is saying thank you to the Lord Jesus Christ.‚Äù¬†
After the hurried sessions in Berlin, Jacco had work to do rounding out and finishing the songs. He and Charlie added percussion overdubs and cosmic ambient sonics. ‚ÄúThe studio had a lot of analog electronic instruments,‚Äù says Jacco, ‚Äúand I have a weak spot for German electronic music from the ‚Äò70s, flavors that had Zambian vibes. This is a more futuristic album than Zango, and they trusted me in the creative process. I felt honored to be allowed to experiment.‚Äù¬†
True to that futuristic spirit, Jagari and Patrick are looking ahead, not back. ‚ÄúThe Rolling Stones?‚Äù says Jagari. ‚ÄúHow long have they been together? A long, long time. They have money, but they're still doing something they love. I think it's the same thing with us. My hope is that the
longer we stay together, whether with the young ones, the old ones, whoever can fit into the genre, they're welcome.‚Äù Patrick concurs, ‚ÄúThere's more to come, and more songs to share with the world.‚Äù

Derrick ‚ÄúDuckie‚Äù Simpson the ‚ÄúGong Gong Gullie‚Äù is the founder and leader for reggae‚Äôs BLACK UHURU. Although going through numerous lead singers and musicians they have remained to be one of the most recognized and prolific reggae band for over 45 years. The Group‚Äôs line up is Duckie Simpson, Andrew Bees, and Elsa Green.
¬†
The roots of BLACK UHURU were formed in Kingston Jamaica‚Äôs Waterhouse district also known as ‚ÄúFirehouse‚Äù in the early 60‚Ä≤s. Though considered to be one of Jamaica‚Äôs toughest neighbourhoods it‚Äôs home to several other reggae singers and musicians. It was where Duckie Simpson grew up and learned to sing from boyhood friends Winston ‚ÄúPipe‚Äù Matthews and Lloyd ‚ÄúBread‚Äù McDonald of Wailing Souls and Bob Marley. He recorded four tracks with Wailing Souls before forming his own group.
¬†
The original Uhuru‚Äôs (Swahili for freedom) were Derrick ‚ÄúDuckie‚Äù Simpson, Ervin ‚ÄúDon Carlos‚Äù Spencer and Rudolph ‚ÄúGarth‚Äù Dennis. They only recorded a few singles ‚ÄúFolk Songs‚Äù ‚ÄúTime Is On Our Side‚Äù and ‚ÄúSlow Coach‚Äù before separating. Don went solo and Garth joined Wailing Souls.
¬†
Duckie reformed the group adding Michael Rose & Errol ‚ÄúTarzan‚Äù Nelson, both from Waterhouse. They recorded their debut album ‚ÄúLove Crises‚Äù in 1977 at Prince Jammy‚Äôs famous studio in Waterhouse on St. Lucia Road. It was later re-released as ‚ÄúBlack Sounds Of Freedom‚Äù. Errol later left to join The Jayes. He was soon replaced by American female singer & dancer Sandra ‚ÄúPuma‚Äù Jones. They teamed up with drummer Sly Dunbar and bass player Robbie Shakespeare. Together they developed a musical style full of deep bass thumps, loud drum slaps, sharp keyboards, long instrumentals with guitar riffs, whirly back round noises, echos and the signature‚Äùwoh oh oh‚Äôs‚Äù creating they‚Äôre ‚Äúclassic‚Äù sound. Producing hits like ‚ÄúI Love King Sellassie, ‚Äú‚ÄòShine Eye Gals‚Äù, ‚ÄúGeneral Penitentiary‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat is Life‚Äù.
¬†
BLACK UHURU released the albums Red, Chill Out, Sinsemila and Guess Who‚Äôs Coming To Dinner and began to tour the world bringing them to international audiences. It was during this period they started to gain rapid popularity. They opened live shows for the Rolling Stones and the Police. They began to work with other well accomplished producers and musicians. Keith Richards played guitar for the ‚ÄúShine Eye Gal‚Äù track. Dennis Brown ‚ÄúThe Crown Prince of Reggae‚Äù produced the tracks ‚ÄúRent Man‚Äù and Wood For My Fire‚Äù. The track‚Äù Spongi Reggae‚Äù appeared on an episode of The Bill Cosby Show and ‚ÄúParty in Session‚Äù in the movie 1980‚Ä≤s North Shore. BLACK UHURU made reggae history when they won the first ever Grammy Award for reggae music in 1984 for the album Anthem Shortly after the grammy Michael Rose went solo.
¬†
Another Waterhouse resident named Delroy ‚ÄúJunior‚Äù Reid became the new lead singer. They released two albums Brutal and Positive. The Brutal album was nominated for a grammy. They filmed three music videos for the tracks ‚ÄúFire City‚Äù ‚ÄúBrutal‚Äù, and ‚ÄúGreat Train Robbery‚Äù, that track also played on a popular video game Grand Theft Auto. Sadly in 1990, due to ill health, Sandra ‚ÄúPuma‚Äù Jones passed away of cancer. Junior Reid shortly went solo.
¬†
Then the original three re-united. They released four albums Now, Iron Storm, Mystical Truth and Strong. Each album was nominated for grammy. They made an award winning music video for the track ‚ÄúTip Of The Iceberg‚Äù featuring rap star Ice-T in 1992. Eventually splitting up again. Carlos & Dennis left again & Duckie stayed again. This time there was a lawsuit brought amongst the group over the band‚Äôs legal rights in Los Angeles county court. Derrick Simpson won.
¬†
As the new millennium approached there came a new lead singer yet again from Waterhouse named Andrew ‚ÄúBee‚Äôs‚Äù Beckford. They released two albums. Unification was produced by King Jammy & Dynasty was produced by Fitzroy Francis & Duckie. They went on a worldwide tour featuring Sly and Robbie and had the famous producer Scientist as its road engineer. Andrew Bee‚Äôs then went solo.
¬†
In 2007 Duckie & Michael Rose reunited after twenty years. They performed in Jamaica and did one international tour and released the single ‚ÄúDollars‚Äù. In 2011 Duckie reunited with Andrew Bee‚Äôs after ten years. He added female backing vocalist Kaye Star and began touring again performing in South America & America.
¬†
BLACK UHURU recently performed in a Broadway Musical. The red carpeted event ‚ÄúLoving the Silent Tears: A New Musical‚Äù premiered October 27th 2012 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles Ca. They were invited to represent reggae music and performed a new track ‚ÄúMake A Deal‚Äù. And in Las Vegas Nevada BLACK UHURU was recently honoured for its contribution to the entertainment industry. August 31st if now officially ‚ÄúBlack Uhuru Day‚Äù in the city of Las Vegas.
¬†
BLACK UHURU‚Äôs long success has allowed them to become ambassadors of reggae while earning several achievements in the music industry. With 14 full length albums, 7 instrumental dub albums, and 4 live albums they have the highest record sales in reggae music behind Bob Marley. The album Red was voted #23 for Rolling Stone‚Äôs list of ‚Äú100 Greatest Albums of the 1980‚Ä≤s. Aside from winning the first reggae grammy they have been nominated 5 more times. They are the only reggae group to have won the Diamond Awards of Excellence in 1994.
¬†
Despite all of BLACK UHURU‚Äôs change of different singers and musicians the one thing that has always remained is Derrick ‚ÄúDuckie‚Äù Simpson. Much respect to a legendary figure for Reggae Music. The group is recently released a new album ‚ÄòAs the World Turns‚Äô which features Duckie on lead and was good for another Grammy Nomination in the category of ‚ÄòBest Album‚Äô.¬† You can find new Music Videos of the songs ‚ÄòJah Guide ft. Bugle‚Äô and ‚ÄòWar Crime‚Äô on youtube and more is to be expected of the notorious Reggae Band in the near future, stay tuned!

Skinshape is the studio project of British musician and producer William Dorey. Skinshape grew out of a love for old music and the way it sounded. The sound has roots in many genres, but in particular 1960s-70s Funk, Soul, Reggae, Psychedelic Rock, Afrobeat and Folk. He also played with the band Palace as bassist from 2014-2017, and is the co-founder of a reggae label called Horus Records.

Hailed as one of the most exciting live acts on the road today, Roger Clyne & The Peacemakers are musical beacons of the Southwest fueled by witty and insightful lyrics, crunching guitar riffs, a dynamic rhythm section and tequila. RCPM are the only act to release seven consecutive studio albums to land on the top 10 of Billboard‚Äôs Internet Sales Chart, two at No. 1, all released on a 100% independent record label.

Dubbed the ‚ÄúSpringsteen of the Southwest‚Äù by the Asbury Park Press, Roger Clyne and his guitar have toured around the world over his 20-year career, starting with The Refreshments. The seminal Tempe, Arizona band made big waves in the ‚Äô90s both on college and alternative rock radio as well as MTV with the songs ‚ÄúBanditos‚Äù (with the infamous chorus, ‚ÄúEverybody knows that the world is full of stupid people‚Äù) and ‚ÄúDown Together‚Äù as well as writing the theme for TV‚Äôs ‚ÄúKing of the Hill.‚Äù

More than¬†20 years later, Clyne and Refreshments drummer PH Naffah, along with bassist Nick Scropos and lead guitarist Jim Dalton keep the songs of The Refreshments alive, while adding to their own ever growing musical legacy. RCPM‚Äôs latest album is, Native Heart, and marks the 10th studio album released by Roger Clyne & PH Naffah.

A testament to their growing and extremely loyal fan base is the band‚Äôs annual music festival in Rocky Point, Mexico, called Circus Mexicus. What began as a rooftop show thrown together with extension cords and wooden pallets more than 15 years ago has blossomed into a pilgrimage that draws thousands of fans to the once sleepy fishing village. In 2014, fans from 43 states and 7 countries represented at Circus Mexicus.

Clyne not only sings about life in the border-lands, he also produces his own private label top shelf tequila called Mexican Moonshine. And a bottle of Mexican Moonshine Tequila made a well received ‚Äúguest appearance‚Äù on the Rachel Ray Show.

In 2016, Clyne‚Äôs career came full circle as Roger Clyne & The Peacemakers celebrated the 20th anniversary of The Refreshments cult classic debut album, ‚ÄúFizzy Fuzzy Big & Buzzy,‚Äù with a residency at the Yucca Tap Room in their hometown of Tempe, followed by a nationwide tour.
